entry.title: Simplify Your Test Setup: Introducing the Test Starter Concept for Your UI5 Projects
entry.content:
With UI5 version 1.124 (Note: A downport for UI5 1.120 is available with 1.120.24) the test starter concept is officially enabled for UI5 application projects. Previously, this concept was mainly used in UI5 framework libraries. This guide explains how to migrate an application project’s test setup to a test starter-based setup. 

In the previous setup, the central entry point for running tests is webapp/test/testsuite.qunit.html, which usually references testsuite.qunit.js located next to it. Test runners like UI5 Test Runner or WebdriverIO QUnit Service also request both files. 

webapp/test/testsuite.qunit.html

To migrate to the new setup, replace the two script tags with one new script tag. This tag loads the sap/ui/test/starter/createSuite module, references the testsuite.qunit.js file, and configures the test namespace. This module creates the actual test suite based on the configuration in the testsuite.qunit.js file. 

Old

<!doctype html> 
<html> 
    <head> 
        <title>QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp</title> 
        <script src="../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-redirect.js"></script> 
        <script src="testsuite.qunit.js" data-sap-ui-testsuite></script> 
    </head> 
    <body></body> 
</html>

New

<!doctype html> 
<html> 
    <head> 
        <title>QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp</title> 
        <!-- Adjust the paths in the following lines to reflect your component namespace --> 
        <script
            src="../resources/sap/ui/test/starter/createSuite.js"   
            data-sap-ui-testsuite="test-resources/ui5/myapp/testsuite.qunit"
            data-sap-ui-resource-roots='{ 
                "test-resources.ui5.myapp": "./" 
            }' 
        ></script> 
    </head> 
    <body></body> 
</html>

 

webapp/test/testsuite.qunit.js

In the previous setup, the testsuite.qunit.js file registered the relevant test pages. This remains true in the new setup, but the number of configuration options has increased significantly, and the file structure has changed. In the new setup, testsuite.qunit.js must return an object representing the test suite configuration. We describe the available configuration options in detail in UI5 Test Starter – Configuration Options. Unlike the previous setup, the configuration doesn’t reference HTML-based test pages. Instead, it points to test pages written in JavaScript or TypeScript. 

Old

window.suite = function () { 
    var suite = new parent.jsUnitTestSuite(); 
    var aParts = location.pathname.match(/(.*\/)(?:[^/]+)/); 
    var sContextPath = aParts && aParts[1]; 
    suite.addTestPage(sContextPath + "unit/unitTests.qunit.html"); 
    suite.addTestPage(sContextPath + "integration/opaTests.qunit.html"); 
    return suite; 
};

New

sap.ui.define(function () { 
    "use strict"; 

    return {
        name: "QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp", 
        defaults: { 
            // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
            page: "ui5://test-resources/ui5/myapp/Test.qunit.html?testsuite={suite}&test={name}", 
            qunit: { 
                version: 2 
            }, 
            sinon: { 
                version: 1 
            }, 
            ui5: { 
                language: "EN", 
                theme: "sap_horizon" 
            }, 
            coverage: {
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                only: "ui5/myapp/", 
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                never: "test-resources/ui5/myapp/" 
            }, 
            loader: { 
                paths: { 
                    // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                    "ui5/myapp": "../" 
                } 
            } 
        }, 
        tests: { 
            "unit/unitTests": { 
                title: "Unit tests for ui5.myapp" 
            }, 
            "integration/opaTests": { 
                title: "Integration tests for ui5.myapp" 
            } 
        } 
    }; 
});

 

webapp/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.js

Previously, the test pages unitTests.qunit.js and opaTests.qunit.js registered a function to be executed after UI5 booted, loaded all test files (Qunit or OPA5) ,and started the test execution. The new Test starter concept simplifies these files significantly. Their only task is to require all relevant test pages. 

Old

QUnit.config.autostart = false; 

sap.ui.getCore().attachInit(function () { 

    "use strict"; 

    sap.ui.require(["unit/controller/Main.qunit"], function () { 
        QUnit.start(); 
    }); 
});

New

sap.ui.define(["./controller/Main.qunit"]);

 

webapp/test/integration/opaTests.qunit.js

Old

QUnit.config.autostart = false; 

sap.ui.getCore().attachInit(function () { 

    "use strict";

    sap.ui.require(["integration/HelloJourney"], function () { 
        QUnit.start(); 
    });

});

New

sap.ui.define(["./HelloJourney"]);

 

webapp/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html and webapp/test/integration/opaTests.qunit.html

You can now delete webapp/test/unit/unitTests.qunit.html and webapp/test/integration/opaTests.qunit.html, as they are no longer needed.

 

webapp/test/Test.qunit.html

Instead, create a new generic test execution page called webapp/test/Test.qunit.html. This file executes the test pages migrated in the previous step.

<!doctype html> 
<html> 
    <head>
        <meta charset="utf-8" />
        <!-- Adjust the paths in the following lines to reflect your component namespace --> 
        <script
            src="../resources/sap/ui/test/starter/runTest.js" 
            data-sap-ui-resource-roots='{ 
                "test-resources.ui5.myapp": "./" 
            }'
        ></script> 
</head> 
<body class="sapUiBody"> 
    <div id="qunit"></div> 
    <div id="qunit-fixture"></div> 
</body>
</html>

 

TypeScript

Note: The following section is only relevant, if your project is using TypeScript.

With UI5 1.142, TypeScript support for defining a test suite has improved. Simply import the sap/ui/test/starter/config/SuiteConfiguration types offered by UI5.  

import type {SuiteConfiguration} from "sap/ui/test/starter/config"; 

export default { 
    name: "QUnit test suite for the UI5 Application: ui5.myapp", 
    defaults: { 
            // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
            page: "ui5://test-resources/ui5/myapp/Test.qunit.html?testsuite={suite}&test={name}", 
            qunit: { 
                version: 2 
            }, 
            sinon: { 
                version: 1 
            }, 
            ui5: { 
                language: "EN", 
                theme: "sap_horizon" 
            }, 
            coverage: {
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                only: "ui5/myapp/",
                // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                never: "test-resources/ui5/myapp/" 
            }, 
            loader: { 
                paths: {
                    // Adjust the path in the next line to reflect your component namespace
                    "ui5/myapp": "../" 
                } 
            } 
        }, 
        tests: { 
            "unit/unitTests": { 
                title: "Unit tests for ui5.myapp" 
            }, 
            "integration/opaTests": { 
                title: "Integration tests for ui5.myapp" 
            } 
        }
} satisfies SuiteConfiguration;

 

Dive Deeper 

The UI5 Demo Kit provides detailed documentation on the general concept and various configuration options, helping you get the most out of the test starter for your project. For a more interactive learning experience, watch the UI5ers live #43 session, where we presented the test starter concept. 

 

Summary

The new test starter concept simplifies the test setup, reduces the boilerplate code needed to write a QUnit test, and ensures the loading of commonly used testing frameworks (such as QUnit, Sinon.JS, and qunit-reporter). It ensures these testing frameworks and your test modules load asynchronously and comply with the Content Security Policy. It also allows moving the configuration of the testing frameworks out of the test code. We look forward to your feedback and experiences when applying the test starter concept to your UI5 projects.

entry.title: The Only Script you would ever need for Message Logging and Custom Headers in SAP CI
entry.content:
Introduction

If you are familiar with a previous blog I had written on Configurable Custom headers in SAP CI where you could just add more custom headers in SAP CI message just by configuring the iflow and without having to edit the iflow and then transport it you understand how important and useful this solution is.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-ci-user-defined-search-made-easy-and-automated/ba-p/13564262

This solution was however limited in the sense that it didn't allow you to log the payload in the same step, didn't work at all if the value to be logged in custom headers had to be derived from an expression, or if the value to be logged was actually a file path for instance and shouldn't be evaluated as an xpath, or the value was just a constant or if the value was the be derived from a gpath.

This advanced solution enables 360 degree message logging and Custom header logging for all these scenarios.

Solution 

This upgraded Script handles all such cases as we shortly see.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import javax.xml.xpath.XPathFactory;
import javax.xml.xpath.XPathExpression;
import javax.xml.xpath.XPathConstants;
import javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper



def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    def propertyMap = message.getProperties()
     def headers = message.getHeaders();
     def value = headers.get("SAPJMSRetries");
   int SAPJMSRetries = -1;
    if(value != null)
    {
    
      SAPJMSRetries =   Integer.parseInt((String)value);
    }      
    //Read logger from the Message Properties
    String logger = propertyMap.get("logger");
    String logPayloadFileName = propertyMap.get("logPayloadFileName");
    
    
    if(logger != null && logger.equals("1") && SAPJMSRetries == -1){//log payload only once
        if(messageLog != null){
           // messageLog.setStringProperty("Logging#1", "Printing Payload As Attachment")
            if(logPayloadFileName == null)
                logPayloadFileName = "payload";
            messageLog.addAttachmentAsString(logPayloadFileName, body, "text/plain");
         }
    }
    message = logKeys(message);
  return message;
}

def Message logKeys(Message message) 
{
    
def xml = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;

    
    def properties = message.getProperties();
    
    def search_attributes = properties.get("search_attributes");
    def attribute_xpaths = properties.get("attribute_xpaths");
    def json = null;

    if( (search_attributes != null && attribute_xpaths != null) && (!search_attributes.equals("") && !attribute_xpaths.equals("")) )
    {
        def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    
         String[] search_attributes_array = search_attributes.split("#");
         String[] attribute_xpaths_array = attribute_xpaths.split("#");
     


        if(search_attributes_array.length == attribute_xpaths_array.length )
        {
            String saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment = ""; //this is needed if the xpath occurs multiple Runtime
            //as SAP CI monitoring truncates the values if they are too long - in display defeating the purpose
            //of the headers
            
          
        
  
            for(int i=0; i<attribute_xpaths_array.length; i++)
            {
             String temp_value= "";
            
                //check if the attributeXpaths field contains a xpath or a constant value 
                if(( attribute_xpaths_array[i].startsWith("XPATH:") )  ) //if you want to enter a value like /folder1/folder2 enter it just dont add XPATH: in beginning and it would be treated like a constant
                {
                    def xpath_exp = attribute_xpaths_array[i].substring(6,attribute_xpaths_array[i].length());
                    try{
                          def xpath = XPathFactory.newInstance().newXPath()
                          def builder     = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance().newDocumentBuilder()
                          def inputStream = new ByteArrayInputStream( xml.bytes )
                          def records     = builder.parse(inputStream).documentElement
                        XPathExpression expr = xpath.compile(xpath_exp)
                        def nodes = expr.evaluate(  records, XPathConstants.NODESET );
            
                        if(nodes != null)
                        {
                            for(int j = 0; j < nodes.getLength(); j++)
                            {
                                //messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty(search_attributes_array[i], nodes.item(j).getTextContent());
                                temp_value = temp_value+nodes.item(j).getTextContent()+",";
                            }
                            if((temp_value.length() > 1) && temp_value.endsWith(","))
                                temp_value = temp_value.substring(0,temp_value.length()-1);
                        }
                    }
                    catch(Exception e)//what if its a invalid xpath and the person just really has a / in the value then add it as is
                    {
                          temp_value =   attribute_xpaths_array[i];//un adulterated value aded to custom header 
                    }
                }
                else if(attribute_xpaths_array[i].startsWith("GPATH:"))
                {
                    try{
                    if(json == null)
                        json = new JsonSlurper().parseText(xml)//ignore the variable name its json
                        
                     def gpath = attribute_xpaths_array[i].substring(6,attribute_xpaths_array[i].length());
                     
                    temp_value =   (Eval.me('json', json, "json.${gpath}")).toString();
                    
                    }
                    catch(Exception e)
                    {
                        //nothing to be done here. If this fails this shouldn't impact message processing in any way by design.
                         messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("Exception Encountered in Logging", e.message, "text/plain");
                    }
                }
                else//it doesnt contain any / hence it is not a xpath which tells us not to treat it as an xpath and might just be an Expression
                {
                  temp_value =   attribute_xpaths_array[i];//un adulterated value aded to custom header 
                }
                if(temp_value != null)
                {
                    //temp_value = temp_value;
                    messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty(search_attributes_array[i], temp_value);
                    saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment = saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment + search_attributes_array[i] + " : " +temp_value+"\n";
                }

            }
            if(saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment != null && !saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment.equals("") && saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment.length() > 200)
                 messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("FullTextOfTruncatedCustomHeaders", saveCustomHeadersAsAnAttachment, "text/plain");
               
        }
    }

        return message;
}

 

Let's consider following XML sample as inbound XML payload

<Invoice>
  <InvHeader>
    <InvNumber>4385689</InvNumber>
    <CustName>Cust 1</CustName>
  </InvHeader>
  <InvLineItem>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>100</ItemNum>
    </Item>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>101</ItemNum>
    </Item>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>102</ItemNum>
    </Item>
    <Item>
      <ItemNum>103</ItemNum>
    </Item>
  </InvLineItem>
</Invoice>

 

Iflow- 

You just need a content modifier with the logger parameters and the actual script after it.

Parameter / Properties format - 

logPayloadFileName - Give the file Name for the log attachment for saving the message as an attachment

logger - 1 : message will be logged as an attachment , 0 : Message wont be logged

search_attributes : Names of the search attributes / Custom headers separated by #

example : HTTPStatus#InvNumber#CustName#ItemNumbers

attribute_xpaths : Values of the custom headers specified above in same order separated by #, Keep data type as java.lang.String

example :

${header.CamelHttpResponseCode}#XPATH://InvNumber#XPATH://CustName#XPATH://InvLineItem/Item/ItemNum

 

 

As you can see from the message log the Custom headers were created from the supplied expression, and XPATH's, if there were multiple xpath matches all those values were concatenated, separated by ",". If you only want only the first xpath matche value do specify [0] explicitly.

 

 A salient feature is that the allowed character limit for a header is 100 characters, In case this limit is exceeded the script will create an attachment as well for that particular header as the SAP CI custom header would display only 100 characters.

And here is the MPL attachment saved with your custom name

 

Let's have a look at a JSON Payload as an input example

{
	"Invoice": {
		"InvHeader": {
			"InvNumber": 4385689,
			"CustName": "Cust 1"
		},
		"InvLineItem": {
			"Item": [
				{
					"ItemNum": 100
				},
				{
					"ItemNum": 101
				},
				{
					"ItemNum": 102
				},
				{
					"ItemNum": 103
				}
			]
		}
	}
}

search_attributes : 

HTTPStatus#InvNumber#CustName#ItemNumbers#ArchiveFilePath

attribute_xpaths

${header.CamelHttpResponseCode}#GPATH:Invoice.InvHeader.InvNumber#GPATH:Invoice.InvHeader.CustName#GPATH:Invoice.InvLineItem.Item*.ItemNum#/Folder1/Folder2/File1.txt

This should now add the custom headers in exactly same way as it added for the previous XML input and should also add the file path which starts with : so as to tell the script to not evaluate it as a XPATH, and should also add the expression. The GPATHS should start with "GPATH:"



Result:

 

One more important feature is that it checks SAPJMSRetries header and if this is used in a JMS flow this will only add MPL attachment 1 time. 

So use it in your iflows and do add the blog link in your script for helping operations team understand how this works.

don't forget to make the search_attributes and attributes_xpaths externalized parameters, that way you would never have to change the artifact and transport it if you need additional custom headers ever.

entry.title: Re: Creating a Hybrid CAP (Node.js) Profile with PostgreSQL on BTP from Business Application Studio
entry.content:
Hi @arunkrishnamoorthy1988, 

Thank you for pointing out this issue. After relaunching the application, I observed the same problem.

The issue was caused by PostgreSQL requiring an SSL-encrypted connection while CAP/Node was unable to validate the server certificate, which resulted in a TLS handshake failure and a connection timeout.

The solution consists of providing the correct certificate so that rejectUnauthorized: true can be used, ensuring both encryption and proper certificate validation.

"ssl": {
  "rejectUnauthorized": true,  
  "ca": "<same_as_sslcert>"
},

I have updated the blog accordingly. Thank you for your feedback !

entry.title: Re: calculate with boolean
entry.content:
Don't confuse ABAP_BOOL type to store the characters 'X' (true) or space (false) with the boolean algebra.

The boolean algebra can be done with ABAP bit operators (example proposed) on variables of type X or XSTRING.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Source to Contract 2601 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community, and welcome to our 2602 Key Innovations blog.
In this post, we’re sharing the main updates included in the Q1 2026 release for SAP Ariba source-to-contract solutions.

Here’s a closer look at what’s new this quarter.



SAP Ariba Contract Management

Generating Contract Summaries in SAP Ariba Contracts Using AI (SCONTR-1266)

When buyers or suppliers open a contract workspace, SAP Ariba Contracts now automatically generates a contract summary. The summary is based on the contract header information and is created using SAP AI Core services.

This applies to both new and existing contracts. If contract details change during the lifecycle, users can generate a new version of the summary. If the generated summary is not satisfactory, users can retry, within a predefined limit. The retry limit can be adjusted through configuration of the SAP AI Core instance, if needed.

This change helps users get a quick overview of a contract without reviewing the full document immediately.

 

Excluding Ad Hoc Tasks During Baseline-to-Supplier Contract Data Transfer (SCONTR-1556)

During pre-award negotiations, supplier contracts are often created by copying data from a baseline contract. With this release, buyers can configure the system to exclude ad hoc tasks during this data transfer.

Ad hoc tasks are typically not inherited from templates and are often informal or exploratory in nature. If copied into supplier contracts, they can unintentionally become binding steps. Excluding these tasks helps ensure that supplier contracts include only the required contractual information.

 

SAP Ariba Guided Sourcing

Enhancements to Manual Award Scenarios (SOURCE-2594)

Manual award scenarios in guided sourcing have been updated to improve usability when allocating items or lots to multiple suppliers.

Users can now open an "Allocate Award" popup from the award allocation panel. This popup allows users to:

  • Allocate awards by percentage or quantity

  • Enter allocation values for each supplier

  • View the total allocated value

  • Apply or save allocations in a single place

These changes reduce the need to scroll through long lists when working with multiple suppliers.

 

Modifying Event Duration and Searching Sourcing Requests Using Joule (SOURCE-2534)

Joule can now be used to adjust the duration of open RFP and RFI events. If an event includes a task, the approver must still approve the timing change for it to take effect. Auction event durations cannot be modified using Joule.

Joule can also be used to view sourcing requests created within a specific timeframe and to open a specific sourcing request directly.

 

Creating Optimization Scenarios Based on Score (SOURCE-2690)

For guided sourcing events where scoring is enabled, buyers can now create optimization scenarios with the objective of maximizing score.

A new "Maximize Score" option has been added to the "Create Scenario" page. This allows award scenarios to be based on overall scoring results, rather than other criteria alone.

The Q1 2026 release introduces targeted updates across contract management and guided sourcing. Each change is designed to reduce unnecessary steps and make existing workflows easier to manage.

These features can be adopted independently, depending on your current setup and processes.

Stay tuned for our additional upcoming blog posts and follow me to stay informed on upcoming feature releases across SAP Ariba. Once, these items are officially released on February 14th, the feature reference IDs (i.e. SC-22524) can help to find more detailed information on http://help.sap.com.

Thank you for being a part of the SAP Ariba community and we look forward to continuing our journey of innovation together!

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • What’s New

entry.title: Using Migration Assessment to Plan Your SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration
entry.content:
As customers transition from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, one of the main challenges is gaining early and reliable visibility into the complexity of the existing integration landscape. Without concrete data, migration planning often relies on assumptions, increasing both risk and uncertainty.

The Migration Assessment capability in SAP Integration Suite addresses this challenge by automatically analyzing SAP Process Orchestration integration scenarios and evaluating migration readiness, required adjustments, and technical effort based on a defined rule set. Instead of subjective estimates, it provides fact-based insights that can be directly used for planning, sizing, and architectural decision-making.

This blog post provides a deep technical walkthrough of how the Migration Assessment works and explains how to interpret its results to build a structured and concrete migration plan.

Overview of Migration Assessment

The Migration Assessment in SAP Integration Suite automatically analyzes your on-premise SAP Process Orchestration integration scenarios and evaluating migration readiness, required adjustments, and technical effort based on a defined rule set. It extracts SAP Process Orchestration objects (e.g., Integration Directory, Enterprise Service Repository) and applies a set of predefined rules to gauge technical readiness and technical migration effort.

BTP Solution Architecture

In a typical setup, your on-premise SAP Process Orchestration (with its Integration Directory and ESR) connects via Cloud Connector to the SAP Integration Suite tenant. Within SAP Integration Suite, the Migration Assessment application uses the configured HTTP destination to call the SAP Process Orchestration APIs and extract all integration artifacts. See more information about how to prepare the SAP Cloud Connector in Add an SAP Process Orchestration System.

Prerequisites: To use Migration Assessment, make sure to check the prerequisites in What Is Migration Assessment?

Connecting to the SAP Process Orchestration System and Running the Assessment

Once prerequisites are in place, in summary these are the next steps:

  1. Configure Cloud Connector, exposing the SAP Process Orchestration system.
  2. Add a new system in the Migration Assessment tool.
  3. Create Data Extraction Request.
  4. Create Scenario Evaluation.

It’s not the focus of this blog to go over the process of setup and running the Extraction/Evaluation. You can find a step-by-step details in the Discovery Center mission Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite or the tutorial Use the Migration Assessment Application. With that, you can produce the outputs (PDF/Excel reports) that we will focus on the next sections.

Rules, Assessment Categories and T-Shirt Sizing

A rule consists of multiple parameters and conditions where each interface evaluated will be checked against, each of which has an assessment category, and a weight assigned to it. Based on these weights and categories, the application calculates the estimated effort, which means that some parameters, and therefore rules, have a bigger influence on the final effort estimation than others.

The Migration Assessment categories indicate how a specific functionality in an integration scenario can be implemented in SAP Integration Suite:

  • Ready to migrate: Scenarios fully match SAP Integration Suite capabilities and can be migrated manually or semi-automatically. Minor adaptations or configuration adjustments may still be required post-migration, but no changes to the end-to-end integration design are needed.
  • Adjustment required Scenarios partially match SAP Integration Suite capabilities. Migration is possible, but changes to the end-to-end integration design are required, such as protocol conversions or source/target system adjustments.
  • Evaluation required: Scenarios cannot be directly migrated and require manual analysis. This typically indicates unsupported functionality, custom code and mainly unclear dependencies, requiring manual analysis and possible redesign or re-implementation.

Please note: Each rule has its own assessment category, and a single interface might contain multiple detected rules in it, therefore, the final interface assessment category is based on the “worst” category. In other words, if an interface has at least one rule that is Evaluation Required, the entire interface is classified as such.

The Evaluation Scenarios Dashboard provides an aggregated view of these results, presented as a pie chart along with a summarized list of integration scenarios:

For a more granular view, you can export the Excel report, which provides detailed information for each interface. These details are explained in the following sections.

The T-Shirt size (Small, Medium, Large, Extra Large) reflects the total weighted effort. The Migration Assessment sums the “weight” of all rules triggered by that interface, that will serve to determine the interface size for all that matters (e.g., how many senders, receivers, mappings, attributes in adapter for specific scenarios).

Please Note: SAP provides a rough effort estimation for the technical migration based on the t-shirt and assessment category.

 

The full list of available rules can be accessed directly in the application under Configure > Rules. All rules in this list are active, and each rule includes a short description explaining exactly what is being evaluated:

The Type column indicates how a rule evaluates a specific value or interval. The following rule types are used:

  • ValueMatchRule: Evaluates a specific condition or extracted attribute against exact values. This is typically used for true/false checks or validations against a predefined list of static values.
  • RangeSumRule: Evaluates multiple values of the same attribute that may occur across different objects (for example, mappings or service interfaces) and checks the aggregated result against defined intervals. This rule type is commonly used for counts such as number of parameters, operations, or fields.
  • RangeRule: Evaluates multiple values of the same attribute against defined intervals without aggregation. This is typically used when assessing thresholds across individual occurrences, such as multiple parameters or operations.

Please note: The Factset attribute is used internally by SAP and is not relevant for the analysis.

By selecting a rule, you can view detailed information about the values or intervals being evaluated:

In this example, the rule is used to determine which message mapping type is used in an interface. If an interface contains multiple mappings, the same rule may appear multiple times in the Excel report, with one line per mapping and its corresponding result.

This rule is of type ValueMatchRule, meaning that Migration Assessment checks for specific values.

  • Rule Match Value: Contains the value being evaluated by the rule.
  • Characteristics: Used to further qualify or subgroup the same rule. In this case, it identifies whether the mapping originates from Extended Receiver Determination (EXT_RCV_DET) or from the standard Receiver Interfaces (RECEIVER_IF) structure.
  • Assessment Category: Determines the assessment category assigned to the interface for this specific rule.
  • Weight: Represents the effort contribution of this rule. For example, if five Java mappings are used within the same interface (across multiple operations or inbound interfaces), this rule alone would contribute a total weight of 150 (5 × 30)

Results Walkthrough (Excel Report)

In this section, we will provide a walkthrough on the excel report. To generate it, navigate to your evaluated scenario, on the dashboard, and click on Export. You’ll be shortly asked to download the .XLSX file.

Full Evaluation Results

This sheet lists every integration scenario and shows each rule that was triggered. For each rule-hit you see details like the rule name, match value, rule category, and weight.

As described in the previous section in this blog, the column “Sub Characteristic” refers to any relevant sub-grouping used for the same rule and value. The list of possible matches and intervals can be found in the Configure > Rules page.

Interpreting Results (Examples):

  • If an integration scenario has any rule flagged as “Evaluation Required” (for example, it uses a custom adapter/module), the whole integration scenario will be Evaluation Required. Otherwise it will end up as Ready to Migrate or Adjustment Required depending on other rules.
  • Sorting this sheet by Weight (descending) quickly highlights the scenarios with the highest effort for a singular functionality/use case. These large-weight cases often involve interfaces with a big number of operations, receivers, etc., as per defined in the range-based rules.
  • Filtering on Assessment Category = Evaluation required or Adjustment required isolates the critical cases that need manual analysis or post-migration activities for certain. While it’s expected that rules with Ready to Migrate category will have no effort for the migration, there might be cases where a minor-post migration activity within Cloud Integration is necessary.
  • You can group in the sheet related rules. For example, you might see rules that bring the names of custom adapter and adapter modules, unsupported JDBC drivers, unsupported OS commands, usage of external dependencies, etc. This hints at one-time modernization steps, e.g. “Replace all interfaces using a certain module with the same clean core approach”. That, once done, help multiple interfaces.

To prepare a successful migration strategy, it’s important to take notes of each one of these “findings” and use the SAP best practices to decide which concrete approach will be used afterwards. These notes will also help you, in case a Proof-of-Concept is necessary in order to verify for a certain adaptation use case.

Eval by Integration Scenario

This sheet summarizes results per interface. This view is great for sizing and license planning. For example, you can remove interfaces from the list and still use the “effort” column to manually recalculate the total migration effort. The sheet also shows message throughput per interface.

These Message Throughput are important for estimating the required Integration Suite license (message-based billing).

For synchronous messages, you might need to check if synchronous messages are logged on the Message Overview Monitor as per the SAP Note 2442373. Make sure to read throughout the note and agree or not with any additional overhead due to the additional message logging in case this is not enabled, and you want to collect also such data.

Additionally you can also have the Message Size and Message Processing Time if you have enabled the performance monthly collection as per the SAP Note 3300008.

For more information of what is the definition of a Message on SAP Integration Suite refer to the SAP Note 2942344 and Discovery Center.

Please Note: The message metrics can also give a hint for inactive interfaces – those with zero messages – which might even be candidates for decommission (though a longer data collection period is recommended before deciding an interface is truly unused).

  • Type: Qualify if the interface is “Integrated Configuration” (ICO) or “Receiver Determination” (RD) from a Dual-Stack installation.
  • Integration Scenario: Identification of the interface with the same naming for both Java-Only and Dual-Stack scenarios: SenderParty|SenderComponent|SenderInterface|SenderInterfaceNamespace|ReceiverParty|ReceiverComponent.
  • Weight: Total weight calculated for the integration scenario based on all applicable rules.
  • T-Shirt Size: T-Shirt size derived from the total weight according to the defined SAP intervals.
  • Message Throughput (30 Days): Message volume collected from Message Monitor (Message Status Overview). Please note:
  • In scenarios with multiple receivers, only outbound messages are counted; inbound entries are excluded.
  • Only successfully processed messages are considered.
  • Average Message Size in Bytes (30 Days): Collected from Performance Monitor, using the Last Month time range with a 1-month aggregation interval.
  • Average Message Processing Time in Milliseconds (30 Days): Collected from Performance Monitor, using the Last Month time range with a 1-month aggregation interval.
  • Maximum Message Size in Bytes (30 Days): Collected from Performance Monitor, using the Last Month time range with a 1-month aggregation interval.
  • Assessment Category: Final category assigned to the interface. If at least one rule is classified as Evaluation Required, the interface is categorized accordingly. The same logic applies to Adjustment Required. If no rules fall into these categories, the interface remains Ready to Migrate.
  • Min Effort Required (Hours): Minimum estimated technical effort for migrating a single interface, based on its Assessment Category and T-Shirt size.
  • Max Effort Required (Hours): Maximum estimated technical effort for migrating a single interface, based on its Assessment Category and T-Shirt size.
  • Average Effort Required (Hours): Average estimated technical effort for migrating a single interface, based on its Assessment Category and T-Shirt size.
  • Extraction Status: Indicates whether the interface was successfully extracted and evaluated:
  • Extracted with Warnings The evaluation ran, but some interface details could not be fully analyzed. This may occur if sender or receiver agreements could not be retrieved, or if inbound or outbound service interface details were missing. Find below some messages you might find:
    • Extraction of Default Service Interface could not identify a SoftwareComponentVersionID for Service Interface: 'x' for integration scenario: 'x' – Indicates that no Software Component Version was selected for the sender interface in the Integrated Configuration or Sender Agreement. As a result, the tool could not retrieve Service Interface details and only partially assessed the interface.
    • Some receivers can't be determined because Extended Receiver Determination is used with "Allow Arbitrary Receivers". Therefore, the interface will be partially assessed, excluding all receiver-specific rules. – Occurs when wildcard receivers are combined with extended receiver determination. In this case, the Migration Assessment cannot determine the receiver list at design time, so all receiver-specific rules are skipped.
    • Some receivers can't be determined because one or more receiver conditions use XPath expressions. Therefore, the interface will be partially assessed, excluding all receiver-specific rules. – Indicates that receiver determination is based on XPath expressions. Since these are evaluated at runtime, the tool cannot determine the receiver list at design time and excludes receiver-specific rules.
    • Message throughput for this interface could not be determined using the Scenario Identifier. Reported values may be inaccurate. – The tool found message throughput data but could not match it uniquely using the Scenario Identifier. Reported values may be inaccurate and should be validated.
    • Multiple Scenario Identifiers are identified for the same interface while counting the message throughput. Reported values may be inaccurate – Indicates that a 1:1 relationship between the interface and Message Monitor entries could not be established. This typically occurs when multiple variants of the same sender interface exist (for example, sender wildcard or multiple virtual receivers), which may lead to inaccurate throughput figures.
    • Couldn't find sender agreement (inbound processing). – Indicates that the interface does not contain a Sender Agreement.
    • Couldn't find receiver agreement (outbound processing). - Indicates that the interface does not contain a Receiver Agreement.
  • Extracted with Errors The interface could not be extracted and was therefore excluded from the evaluation. This typically results from consistency issues, such as an operation mapping defined in the Integration Directory but not retrievable from the Enterprise Services Repository. In such cases, verify that the relevant software components are correctly assigned to Integration Directory objects (for example, Integration Configuration Objects or Sender/Receiver Agreements). Find below some messages you might find:
    • Unable to determine Sender components, Receiver components and Receiver Interfaces. The scenario will not be evaluated. – Indicates that dependent objects could not be identified during receiver determination, pointing to an inconsistency in the configuration.
    • No object of type: xxx could be found with the following search criteria -  Object: yyy  SWCGUID: zzz – Although the tool attempted to retrieve an object (such as a Service Interface or Message Mapping) using its full identifier, the object does not exist in the ESR. This indicates a design-time inconsistency.
    • Duplicate key xxx found for integrated configuration and dual-stack configuration. The scenarios linked to this key are excluded from extraction and evaluation. To extract these scenarios, use custom extraction to handle them separately. – Indicates that the same interface exists in both Integration Configuration and Receiver Determination formats. To evaluate such scenarios, create a new extraction Data Extraction and use the custom extraction option instead of a complete extraction to select only one of them.  
    • Couldn't find service interface details. - The Migration Assessment relies on ESR Service Interface definitions to extract message structure and operation details. If the object exists only in the Integration Directory, the tool cannot access the required ESR metadata.

This is common in “dummy passthrough” or file-to-file scenarios, where no ESR objects are created. While such cases are normally ignored, an error is raised when a Service Interface and Software Component are referenced in the ICO or in Sender/Receiver Agreements but cannot be retrieved from the ESR. This indicates a missing ESR reference or an incorrectly maintained Software Component ID.

Recommendation:
Always review the extraction logs before reading the evaluation results to ensure the assessment data is complete and reliable. You can download it from the Extraction Dashboard page as below:

Scenario Technical Details

The Scenario Technical Details sheet provides a consolidated and detailed view of each integration scenario’s technical metadata. It includes sender and receiver system information, communication channels, mappings, and receiver or interface determination details, making it particularly valuable for migration planning and interface consolidation.

  • Integration Scenario: Unique interface identification, using the same naming convention for both Java-only and dual-stack scenarios: SenderParty|SenderComponent|SenderInterface|SenderInterfaceNamespace|ReceiverParty|ReceiverComponent.
  • Interface Type: Indicates whether the interface is Synchronous or Asynchronous.
  • Sender Communication Party / Sender Communication Component: Identifies the sender party and component. In wildcard sender scenarios, one line is provided per sender.
  • Interface: Sender (outbound) interface name.
  • Sender Channel / Sender Adapter: Sender communication channel name and adapter type.
  • Type of Receiver Determination: Indicates whether Standard or Extended Receiver Determination is used.
  • Receiver Rule Type / Receiver Rule: Specifies whether a Local Rule or Receiver Rule is used and provides the rule name, if applicable.
  • Receivers Condition: Full condition string for each receiver. Interfaces with multiple receivers appear as multiple lines.
  • Operation Mapping / Message Mapping for Extended Receiver Determination: Operation and message mapping names used when Extended Receiver Determination is applied.
  • Operation-Specific/Not Operation-Specific: Indicates whether the interface configuration is Operation-Specific, Not Operation-Specific, or N/A.
  • Operation: Interface operation name
  • Receiver Interface Conditions: Full condition string for inbound interfaces. One line is provided per inbound interface when multiple exist.
  • Operation Mapping: Operation Mapping name for a single receiver interface.
  • Message Mapping (Request): Message Mapping name for a single receiver interface. Multiple lines appear if multiple mapping steps exist.
  • Mapping Type (Request): Mapping implementation type: Graphical Mapping, Java Mapping, XSLT Mapping, or N/A.
  • Message Mapping (Response): Message Mapping name for a single receiver interface. Multiple lines appear if multiple mapping steps exist.
  • Mapping Type (Response): Mapping implementation type: Graphical Mapping, Java Mapping, XSLT Mapping, or N/A.
  • Receiver Communication Party / Receiver: Identifies the receiver party and component. In wildcard sender scenarios, one line is provided per sender.
  • Receiver Interface: Receiver (inbound) interface name.
  • Receiver Channel / Receiver Adapter: Receiver communication channel name and adapter type.

Interpreting Results (Examples):

  • Group interfaces by sender and/or receiver to plan migration waves. A common strategy is to migrate interfaces belonging to the same consumer application together
  • Identify mappings reused across multiple interfaces. Pivot tables can help detect reusable artifacts and plan their migration as shared integration packages.
  • Analyze the variety of adapters and communication channels used on both sender and receiver sides to identify standardization or modernization opportunities
  • Understand how many asynchronous scenarios exist in the landscape. This can support decisions around using the Pipeline concept in Cloud Integration and designing the Partner Directory for specific scenarios such as XI or IDoc. For more information about Pipeline Concept, see Introducing the new pipeline concept in Cloud Integration and Pipeline Concept.

Modernization Recommendations

The assessment also provides Modernization Recommendations based on SAP integration strategy. These suggestions tell you where and how to modernize your interfaces. The recommendations fall into different categories as the below examples:

  • Integration Style: e.g. adopt event-driven patterns or replace polling with triggers.
  • Mapping: e.g. use standard, cloud-friendly mapping techniques (graphical mappings) instead of legacy Java or ABAP mappings.
  • Monitoring & Operation: e.g. enable standardized alerting, use SAP Integration Suite monitoring, or remove hard-coded operations.
  • Protocol: e.g. switch from JMS or File-based protocols to API-based protocols, or prefer SOAP APIs over IDocs.
  • Security: e.g. use OAuth2 or certificate-based auth instead of basic authentication.

You can check the help documentation with the complete description of each category and each recommendation in Modernization Recommendations.

  • Integration Scenario: Unique interface identification, using the same naming convention for both Java-only and dual-stack scenarios: SenderParty|SenderComponent|SenderInterface|SenderInterfaceNamespace|ReceiverParty|ReceiverComponent.
  • Modernization Category: Recommendation category as defined in the Modernization Recommendations help documentation.
  • Possible Modernization Item: Indicates the source or aspect of the interface identified as a candidate for modernization.
  • Recommendation: Target modernization recommendation as defined in the Modernization Recommendations help documentation.

Please note that a single interface may have multiple modernization recommendations.

While some modernization items may represent quick wins, others can require significant changes to the interface design or even to the underlying business process. It is therefore important to carefully assess the impact of each recommendation during the planning phase. If certain improvements cannot be implemented as part of the migration project, the assessment results can still serve as a baseline for defining a long-term modernization roadmap to be executed after the migration.

API and Business Event Recommendations

Beyond the general modernization recommendations, Migration Assessment can go a step further by identifying opportunities to modernize IDoc and BAPI (RFC)-based integrations. Based on the detected usage, it proposes suitable SOAP and OData APIs available in SAP S/4HANA, helping you align your integrations with SAP’s recommended, API-based integration patterns.

These insights are available in the API Recommendations Excel sheet.

Similarly, the Business Event Recommendations Excel sheet provides recommendations for redesigning integrations using an event-driven architecture, based on the business events available in SAP S/4HANA.

  • Object ID: Name of the IDoc or BAPI identified as a candidate for modernization..
  • Type (BAPI/IDOC): Indicates whether the object is an IDoc or a BAPI. Currently, only these object types are supported.
  • API/Business Event: Name of the target API or Business Event proposed for modernization.
  • Technical Name: Technical name of the API or Business Event. This can be used to search directly in SAP Business Accelerator Hub or to activate the service in SAP S/4HANA.
  • Protocol: For APIs, indicates whether the service is available as OData V2, OData V4, or SOAP.
  • Solution: Indicates the SAP solution in which the API or Business Event is available. Currently, Migration Assessment proposes objects available in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

Notes:

  • If the same API is available in multiple solutions and/or protocols, the values are listed as comma-separated entries in the Technical Name, Protocol, and Solution columns.
  • A single IDoc or BAPI may be replaced by multiple APIs depending on the business process, resulting in multiple rows for the same object in the Excel report.

You can find a practical example how you can explore, analyze and modernize an interface using such recommendations in Modernizing for a Clean Core: IDoc to Events & APIs in SAP PI/PO to Integration Suite Migration and Modernizing RFC/BAPI-based Integrations for a Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite.

Effort Estimation

The Effort Estimation sheet consolidates the total technical migration effort by aggregating the estimated days associated with each T-shirt size, resulting in an overall execution estimate (for example, “Project Effort = 123 days”).

This estimate covers only the technical re-implementation of interfaces, ideally using the migration tool where applicable. It explicitly excludes activities such as prepare, explore, validation, and cutover.

A learning curve factor is applied to the calculation. When multiple interfaces share the same size and category, they tend to be similar, allowing developers to become more efficient over time. This efficiency gain has been consistently observed across multiple migration projects and is reflected in the final effort calculation.

The intervals used for the learning curve factor are outlined below:

Number of Interfaces x T-shirt size

Learning Curve

10-50

25%

51-100

27%

101-200

30%

201-500

33%

501 or more

35%

Use this estimate as a baseline for building your project schedule, taking into account the effort required for critical phases such as testing, the tools and accelerators available to support the migration, and the external parties that must be aligned to ensure a successful go-live.

Please note that the technical execution effort provided by the Migration Assessment may vary depending on the technical team’s expertise and the scope of modernizations included in the migration journey.

In the Excel file, the calculations are presented in two tables. The first table includes interfaces categorized as Ready to Migrate and Adjustment Required, while the second table contains interfaces categorized as Evaluation Required.

Interfaces under Evaluation Required typically need manual analysis and are therefore subject to higher estimation deviations. You may sum the results of both tables as-is for an initial migration effort estimate, but only after reviewing the Evaluation Required scenarios to ensure the figures are reasonable.

Conclusion

The Migration Assessment reports provide a concrete, data-driven foundation for your SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite migration plan. They clearly identify which interfaces are straightforward to migrate (Ready to Migrate and Adjustment Required) and which require deeper analysis (Evaluation Required), while quantifying the expected effort in days.

Use these insights to structure the migration into logical phases. Although it’s normal to have a single structured project to migrate all the interfaces, you can also start, for example, by migrating all Ready to Migrate interfaces within a specific business area (low effort), while in parallel analyzing the Evaluation Required interfaces that may need redesign or even preparing a Proof-of-Concept to validate a particular modernization. The assessment also promotes consistency by identifying shared artifacts, so mappings or channels are reworked only once, and by proposing modernization opportunities such as protocol changes or API adoption to future-proof your integrations.

In short, don’t migrate blindly. Leverage the Migration Assessment to uncover hidden dependencies and effort drivers before implementation begins. This allows you to organize delivery into manageable deployment waves, assign realistic effort estimates to each wave and make informed technical decisions early.

For additional questions related to the SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite migration, see FAQ – Migration from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite.

Additional References

  • Future-Proofing Enterprise Agility with SAP Integration Suite and Clean Core Principles
  • Modernization Recommendations
  • A look into the Migration Assessment Modernization Recommendation - Clean Core
  • Modernize RFC Sender Communications into API-Based protocols in Cloud Integration
  • Modernize RFC Receiver Communications into API-Based Protocols in Cloud Integration

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - IS - How to become a SAP Integration Suite Consultant beyond SAP CPI - SAP APIM Part I
entry.content:
We shouldn't really consider adding SAP APIM by default in front of SAP CPI endpoints unless quota, spike arrest , allowlist etc are needed. SAP Reference Architecture for A2A integrations with third parties doesn't suggest anywhere that SAP API management should be used in front of all SAP CI endpoints. 

The argument "protecting SAP CI" endpoints is invalid as SAP CI endpoints are public by design and so are SAP API Management endpoints even though custom. Even if you are consciously removing SAP CI endpoint from SAP CI response headers in post flow in API management, the same concept applies to SAP APIM endpoints. they are exposed. 

 

also SAP CI endpoints were never meant to be hidden. Please understand SAP APIM use cases before suggesting invalid reference Architectures.

entry.title: Re: Purchasing of Fixed Assets
entry.content:
You do not need to wait for settlement for budget availability control. The PO amount is deducted from the WBS budget as a commitment immediately when the PO is created. Settlement is only needed later to move the actual costs to the fixed asset for capitalization.

So the flow is:

  • PO created → Commitment posted to WBS → AVC checks budget in real time.
  • GR/Invoice → Actual costs posted to WBS.
  • Period end → Settlement transfers costs from WBS to asset.

entry.title: Adobe Lifecycle Designer showing an error while downloading

entry.title: Mastering Multipart/Form-Data Uploads in SAP Integration Suite: Solving EOL and Streaming Issues
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of API integration, multipart/form-data remains a standard for uploading files along with associated metadata. While SAP Integration Suite provides several ways to handle attachments, developers often encounter scenarios where standard adapters or simple scripts fall short—especially when a target system requires specific field names, precise content types for each part.

In this blog post, I will demonstrate how to leverage the Apache HttpClient 5 (HC5) library within a Groovy script to build robust, flexible, and high-performance multipart requests.

The Challenge

When integrating with modern Document Management Systems (DMS) or third-party SaaS platforms, you often receive a JSON payload containing a Base64 encoded file. The requirement is usually to transform this into a multipart request where:

  1. Part A is a JSON metadata object.
  2. Part B is the actual binary file.

However, the biggest technical hurdle in manual multipart construction is the handling of EOL (End of Line) characters. According to RFC standards, multipart boundaries and headers must be separated by specific CRLF (\r\n) sequences. SAP Integration Suite’s internal environment often defaults to standard UNIX line endings (LF), which many strict target APIs (like AWS or SAP DMS) will reject as "Malformed Multipart Requests."

The Solution: Apache HttpClient 5 and Groovy

While there are existing methods to handle form-data, using Apache HC5 provides better control over the entity lifecycle. It natively handles the CRLF requirements, ensuring your boundaries are always compliant.

Furthermore, a common pitfall in SAP Integration Suite is the ContentTooLongException when streaming entities. My approach resolves this by explicitly buffering the entity into a byte array before passing it back to the message body, ensuring stability even when the runtime cannot automatically calculate the content length.

The Implementation

To use this script, ensure the Apache HttpClient 5 JARs are added to your Integration Flow resources. This script decodes the Base64 data, and builds the multipart entity with correct line endings.

Libs:

https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.apache.httpcomponents.client5/httpclient5/5.5.1

https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.apache.httpcomponents.core5/httpcore5/5.3.5

 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import org.apache.hc.client5.http.entity.mime.MultipartEntityBuilder
import org.apache.hc.core5.http.HttpEntity
import org.apache.hc.core5.http.ContentType
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper
import java.text.Normalizer
import java.io.ByteArrayOutputStream

def Message processData(Message message) {

    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    // 1. Retrieve and Normalize Filename Properties
    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    def properties = message.getProperties()
    String originalName = properties.get("attachmentName")
    
    String fileName = originalName // e.g., "1347_2024.pdf"
    
    // Extract name without extension for the multipart 'name' field
    String nameWithoutExtension = (fileName.lastIndexOf('.') > 0) 
        ? fileName[0..<fileName.lastIndexOf('.')] 
        : fileName

    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    // 2. Process Payload (JSON -> Base64 -> Bytes)
    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    // Parse the incoming JSON body
    def jsonObject = new JsonSlurper().parse(message.getBody(java.io.Reader))
    
    // Decode the Base64 'data' field into a Byte Array
    byte[] fileBytes = org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Base64.decodeBase64(jsonObject.data)

    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    // 3. Build Multipart Entity
    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    MultipartEntityBuilder builder = MultipartEntityBuilder.create()
    
    // Define the metadata JSON to be sent alongside the file
    String jsonMetadata = '{"origin": "05"}'

    // Part 1: Add JSON Metadata
    builder.addTextBody(nameWithoutExtension, jsonMetadata, ContentType.APPLICATION_JSON)
    
    // Part 2: Add Binary File
    // HC5 automatically ensures CRLF line endings for these parts
    builder.addBinaryBody(nameWithoutExtension, fileBytes, ContentType.APPLICATION_OCTET_STREAM, fileName)
    
    HttpEntity entity = builder.build()

    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    // 4. Finalize Output
    // ---------------------------------------------------------
    // Set the Content-Type header (includes the boundary parameter)
    message.setHeader("Content-Type", entity.getContentType())
    
    // CRITICAL: Write the entity to a ByteArrayOutputStream.
    // Apache HC5 streaming entities often throw "ContentTooLongException" 
    // Writing to a stream buffers the multipart body explicitly.
    ByteArrayOutputStream out = new ByteArrayOutputStream()
    try {
        entity.writeTo(out)
        message.setBody(out.toByteArray())
    } finally {
        out.close()
    }
    
    return message
}

 

Example input:

{
    "size": 56192,
    "data": "<here we have base64data>"
}

Example output:

--httpclient_boundary_cfcb3612-4076-4899-b570-a229c8643589
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="Invoice_47251"
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8

{"origin": "05"}
--httpclient_boundary_cfcb3612-4076-4899-b570-a229c8643589
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="Invoice_47251"; filename="Invoice_47251.pdf"
Content-Type: application/octet-stream

<here we have PDF body>

--httpclient_boundary_cfcb3612-4076-4899-b570-a229c8643589--

 

Key Technical Deep-Dive

  • The EOL (End-of-Line) Fix 
    • Manual string building in Groovy (e.g., using \n) is the primary reason multipart uploads fail. The HTTP specification requires \r\n. By using MultipartEntityBuilder, we outsource this complexity. The library ensures that every part and boundary is wrapped in the correct CRLF sequence, making your integration compatible with strict receivers like Windows-based servers or AWS S3.
  • Avoiding ContentTooLongException
    • Cloud Integration often struggles with "Streaming Entities" when it cannot determine the length of the stream ahead of time. By using ByteArrayOutputStream to write the entity and then converting it to a byte[], we provide a "materialized" body to the SAP message exchange. This avoids the common runtime exception where the system fails to calculate the Content-Length.

Conclusion

Handling multipart/form-data in SAP Integration Suite requires more than just concatenating strings. By leveraging Apache HttpClient 5, we solve the most common "invisible" errors related to line endings (EOL) and streaming length. This approach provides a professional, reusable template for any file-upload scenario.

entry.title: Mastering JWT Creation in SAP Integration Suite (CPI)
entry.content:
Mastering Custom JWT Creation in SAP Integration Suite (CPI)

Before we dive into the "How," let’s look at the "What."

What is a JWT?

A JSON Web Token (JWT) is a compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties. It is commonly used for Authentication and Information Exchange.

A JWT looks like a long string of random characters separated by two dots. It has three distinct parts:

Part

Description

Example Content

Header

Specifies the type (JWT) and the hashing algorithm.

{ "alg": "RS256", "typ": "JWT" }

Payload

The "claims" or data about the user.

{ "userId": "123", "role": "admin" }

Signature

A hash created from the header, payload, and a secret key.

(Cryptographic hash)

Crucial Note: The Payload is encoded, not encrypted. Anyone who intercepts the token can read the data inside (like your user ID).

JSON Web Token (JWT) authentication is a stateless way of verifying users. Instead of the server keeping a "session" in its memory or database to remember who you are, it gives you a digital "passport" (the token) that you carry with you.

How It Works

  1. Sender creates a JWT signed with a secret key and send JWT token to receiver token URL.
  2. Token API: The server verifies token.  If they’re correct, it provides access token to sender.
  3. Sender: Send the actual data request along with access token
  4. Receiver main API: The server verifies access token; if it matches, then accept the data

Pro Tip: You can always debug and visualize your tokens at jwt.io. It is the industry-standard tool for verifying your token structure and signatures.

The Business Scenario: Why do we need this?

Modern integration isn't just about moving data; it’s about moving data securely.

Imagine you are integrating SAP S/4HANA with a premium cloud service like Salesforce, Google Cloud, banks or a Government Tax Portal. These platforms often require OAuth 2.0 JWT Bearer Flow. Instead of a simple password, your SAP CPI tenant must "prove" its identity by sending a digitally signed JSON Web Token (JWT).

Since SAP CPI doesn't have a standard "JWT Creator" step, we use a Groovy script to bridge the gap.

SAP CPI Implementation Guide:

While SAP CPI provides many out-of-the-box adapters, there are times when a receiver system requires a custom JWT signed with a private key. Since there is no standard "JWT Creator" step, we use the power of Groovy Scripting.

Step 1: The Keystore Setup

Ensure you have Created a Key Pair to Monitor > Manage Security > Keystore. Note the alias name.

Step 2: The Content Modifier: Set the Pre-requisite

Before the script, use a Content Modifier to set the following properties. This makes the script dynamic and reusable:

Property

Source & Responsibility

Description

alg

Receiver Requirement (API Provider)

The specific algorithm mandated by the target system (e.g., RS256).

typ

Standard Configuration (Created in CPI)

The token format type; always set to JWT.

iss

Receiver Requirement (API Provider)

The unique identifier (Issuer/Client ID) for your SAP system.

sub

Receiver Requirement (API Provider)

The identity or service account email being authenticated.

aud

Receiver Requirement (API Provider)

The specific URL of the target API's token service.

expiry_time

Flow Logic (Created in CPI)

The business decision on how long a token remains valid.

alias

Security Material (Created in CPI)

The alias of the Key Pair created in the CPI Keystore.

Step 3: The Groovy Script

Technical Breakdown: The 7 Steps to create JWT token

1. Extraction of Metadata (Properties)

The script begins by pulling dynamic values from the Message Properties (set earlier in Content Modifier).

Why? This makes the script reusable across different integration flows by simply changing the properties.

2. Defining the Maps (Data Structuring)

Before we can encode or sign anything, we must organize the raw data into a structured format. We define two Groovy Maps (Key-Value pairs):

  • The Header Map: Contains the metadata, specifically the algorithm (alg) and the type (typ).
  • The Payload Map: Contains the "Claims." This includes identity info (iss, sub, aud) and the calculated expiration timestamp (exp).

Why? Defining maps is the cleanest way to prepare data for JSON conversion. It ensures that the exp claim is treated as a Long integer rather than a string, which is a strict requirement for JWT validation.

3. Base64URL Encoding

Standard JSON strings cannot be sent directly in an HTTP header.

  • The script converts the Maps to JSON and then applies Base64URL encoding.
  • Crucial Step: We use .withoutPadding() because the JWT standard (RFC 7519) forbids the = padding characters used in standard Base64.

4. Construction of the Token (Unsigned)

The encoded Header and encoded Payload are joined using a period (.).

  • Format: encodedHeader.encodedPayload
  • This string serves as the "source of truth" that will be digitally signed in the next step.

5. Digital Signing (The Security Core)

This is the most critical part of the script:

  • Keystore Access: We use the KeystoreService to fetch the Key Pair based on alias.
  • Algorithm: We initialize Signature using SHA256withRSA (the Java equivalent of RS256).
  • The Seal: The private key "signs" the unsigned token. This ensures that if even one character in the payload is changed, the signature will become invalid.

6. Final Assembly

The generated signature is also Base64URL encoded and appended to the end of the string.

  • Final Format: Header.Payload.Signature
  • This completes the three-part structure of a JWT.

7. Output to Header or Body

Finally, the script writes the resulting token back to the SAP CPI Message:

  • Header: It creates a header (e.g., jwtToken/Authorization) prefixed with Bearer , making it ready for an HTTP adapter.
  • Body: I have created for testing purpose

Here is the high-performance script to generate the token.

Groovy

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import com.sap.it.api.keystore.KeystoreService
import com.sap.it.api.ITApiFactory
import java.security.Signature
import java.util.Base64
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // --- 1. Define variables for 3 different parts 
    // a. Header variables
    def alg = message.getProperty("alg")
    def typ = message.getProperty("typ")
    // b. Payload variables
    def iss = message.getProperty("iss")
    def sub = message.getProperty("sub")
    def aud = message.getProperty("aud")
    def expiry_time = message.getProperty("expiry_time")
    long currentTimeInSeconds = new Date().getTime() / 1000L
    long exp = currentTimeInSeconds + (expiry_time.toLong() * 60L)
    // c. signature varable 
    def alias = message.getProperty("Private_KeyPair_alias")

    // --- 2. Define Maps 
    def headerMap = [
        "alg": alg,
        "typ": typ
    ]
    def payloadMap = [
        "iss": iss,
        "sub": sub,
        "aud": aud,
        "exp": exp.toLong() // Ensure numeric value for JWT compliance
    ]

    // --- 3. Encode the data ---
    def encoder = Base64.getUrlEncoder().withoutPadding()
    String encodedHeader = encoder.encodeToString(JsonOutput.toJson(headerMap).getBytes("UTF-8"))
    String encodedPayload = encoder.encodeToString(JsonOutput.toJson(payloadMap).getBytes("UTF-8"))

    // --- 4. Create unsigned token ---
    String unsignedToken = encodedHeader + "." + encodedPayload

    // --- 5. Signed token ---
    // a. Fetch Private Key from CPI Keystore
    def keystoreService = ITApiFactory.getApi(KeystoreService.class, null)
    def keyPair = keystoreService.getKeyPair(alias)
    def privateKey = keyPair.getPrivate()
    // b. Initialize Signature with RS256 algorithm (SHA256withRSA)
    Signature rsa = Signature.getInstance("SHA256withRSA")
    rsa.initSign(privateKey)
    rsa.update(unsignedToken.getBytes("UTF-8"))
    // c. Generate and encode the signature
    String encodedSignature = encoder.encodeToString(rsa.sign())
    
    // --- 6. Final JWT token ---
    String jwtToken = unsignedToken + "." + encodedSignature

    // --- 7. Save it in header ---
    message.setHeader("jwtToken", "Bearer " + jwtToken) // You can give Header name as Authorization
    message.setBody(jwtToken)
    
    return message
}

 

Final Output

After our Groovy script generates the JWT, we pass it in the Authorization Header as a "Bearer Token" to the identity provider.

Header Key: Authorization

Header Value: Bearer <Your_Generated_JWT>

The receiver (e.g., Salesforce, Google, bank or Azure) validates the signature of your JWT using the Public Key you shared with them earlier. If valid, they return a JSON response containing a short-lived Access Token.

Finally, you must extract that Access Token and use it in the Authorization header of your actual data request.

Conclusion

Implementing JWT in SAP CPI gives you the flexibility to connect to modern APIs (Google Cloud, Azure, Salesforce, bank’s API etc.) that require custom claims.

Have you implemented JWT differently in your projects? Let’s discuss in the comments!

#SAP #SAPIntegrationSuite #CPI #JWT #Groovy #API #Integration #SAPCloudPlatform
